Hither swains!  who, whistling blythe,</br>Drive the team, or wield the scythe,</br>Hither Nymphs!  who late were seen</br>Rakeing the new-shaven green,</br>Hither to these shades repair,</br>Merry lads!  and merry fair!</br>Hither come, and sport, and play,</br>This is Cupid's holy-day.

By the silver waves, that steal</br>Soft along yon winding vale,</br>By the radiant blaze of morn,</br>Gilding bright each pearly thorn,</br>By the silken gales, that fly</br>Wanton thro' the cloudless sky;</br>Hither come, and sport, and play,</br>This is Cupid's holy-day.

Hither from yon sunny bank,</br>Laughter, come, with many a prank!</br>Where beside the limpid spring</br>Murm'ring sweet, you gaily sing,</br>Where in zoneless vest you call</br>Echo from her moss-rob'd wall,</br>Hither come, and sport, and play,</br>This is Cupid's holy-day.

Here the Graces hand in hand,</br>Decent form the social band.</br>Here, in purest white array'd</br>Innocence, celestial maid,</br>Bids th' expanded soul to flow,</br>Bids the raptur'd bosom glow,</br>Bids us sport, and bids us play,</br>This is Cupid's holy-day.

Hither, clad in rural dress,</br>Every soft-ey'd shepherdess!</br>Hark!  the youths impatient say,</br>Leave your cotts, and come away—</br>Come, O, come, ye virgin train!</br>Leave your cotts, and seek the plain,</br>Seek the plain, and sport, and play,</br>This is Cupid's holy-day.

Now in order meet advance,</br>Shift the foot, and weave the dance,</br>Trip it ev'ry well-match'd pair,</br>Mirthful, gay, and debonair,</br>While the trembling music flotes,</br>Richly wild, in sprightly notes.</br>While you carol, as you play,</br>This is Cupid's holy-day.

Grateful now the chorus raise</br>Io Hymen!  to thy praise,</br>Io Hymen!  be the song,</br>Ever bright!  and ever young!</br>Hymen!  whom in Cyprus' grove</br>Virtue form'd the friend of Love.</br>Sing of Hymen!  sport, and play,</br>This is Cupid's holy-day.

Should a stranger list to know,</br>Whence our simple, rustic show?</br>Why in vain the corn demands,</br>Bending corn, the reaper's hands?</br>Why your balmy fingers bind</br>Chaplets that may scent the wind?</br>Tell him, as ye sport, and play,</br>This is Cupid's holy-day.

Tell him, from her sacred bow'r</br>Venus sends a fav'rite flow'r,</br>Such, as when, to bless the earth,</br>She gave her little urchin birth;</br>Say, there's not a god but gives</br>Fragrance to the rising leaves:</br>Hence you sport, and hence you play,</br>This is Cupid's holy-day.

Then, if aught in worth he's read,</br>Temper'd brave, or nobly bred,</br>Drop, ye clouds, your mildest dews,</br>Feed its stalk!  and nurse its hues!</br>Ever may the buds be seen</br>Lively, blooming, fresh, and green!</br>Thus he'll wish; and sport, and play,</br>Hailing Cupid's holy-day!</br>
